so every row in a relational table would become a document in your collection of documents a column

mongodb well mongodb and document databases make life easier
there's high availability so in the document relational database world right if you want to make a change
to your table you have to you know go and speak to database admin normally bribe them with donuts threaten them
with management something to make them take your whole database offline to make a simple change
bring it back back up again with mongodb doesn't matter because it's flexible schema you don't have to take
it all offline just to make a change it will be there for you plus if you use um the cloud which will come
onto you shortly we um has high availability because it uses something called replica sets under
the hood which i won't go into too much detail because it gets a bit technical but just think of it as a minimum of
three nodes that form your database cluster and so one's a primary and everything it's called a replica set
because all your data is replicated between those nodes so if one of the nodes goes down for every reason it will
just promote another one to primary and it will just keep going so you won't see down you'll see much few less
chances of downtime because you know it'll just handle it it'll just take care of it you know high
availability from this flexibility as i said you know the scheme is flexible so as your
project evolves and your data evolves so can your database you shouldn't have to be held back or slowed down just because
your relational database can't can't ha can't handle it you know no need to have this big down time just
be flexible you know chill and then of course there's vertical
scaling so this is still existing in a relational database as well so vertical scaling is
this idea that if you need more resources because i don't know maybe you've written something that's suddenly
gone i don't know word or when it was a good example gone from not a lot to suddenly being a massive overnight hit
and suddenly all being hit way much more maybe your database is being you know not essentially appears like it's being
ddosed because you're in usage increases with vertical scaling you just add more
hardware might be more hard disk space might be a better cpu might be more ram
but you know you just it's hard vertical scaling is hardware but the problem with that is that there's a ceiling
eventually you either run out of hardware that exists to put in your server
or it just gets so ridiculously expensive it's not an option anymore and so you know that's one solution just
scale vertically and we can we can do that if you need to but one thing that sets us apart from
relational databases is horizontal scaling because of the way that relational databases work with tables
and everything you they can't be split up for horizontal scaling but that's okay we can
you know if you need if you're doing really well you know you can put it in lots of different places around the world
um and you know having lots of places it's nice and available and you know you can split it up in a way that works and
scale outwards one of the cool things we have as well is something called sharding now sharding's not unusual if you know much
about distributed databases but you know but for those that don't know sharding is basically this idea
that you pick a property on your data and you say right okay use this as a
reference point to break it up if there's lots of it so if it's a huge data set you might want to break it up
think of it a bit like a library in the library they don't shelf books into the library on the shelf in the order they
acquired them willy-nilly they're broken down into shelves by author surname so that you know oh i
want to find something by i don't know uh george rr martin so you will go to m
for martin and find whatever game of thrones book you want to find don't know why i picked that one i've
never even seen game of thrones properly i can't concentrate on it um but yeah so this sharding's the same
thing so in the library world your author surname will be a sharding key to break it all up and so you know you can
you can even break it out since you've got a huge data set rather than having to search through the hundreds of thousands of documents you might have
you split it up into these nice little shards and then go oh cool yeah okay i want to find this and so based on the
sharding key i can just go over here it's much more a subset to look through much better performance
and that's great and we've even introduced something recently called live resharding so if you decide
actually do you know what i want to change what the key is i'm sharding on in my data set we'll you know you can just go in and
say hey i want to use a different different um sharding key it will take care of switching it over
in the back end for you live without you taking your data down so again high availability
